segment.source: This tutorial teaches you how to use JavaScript and HTML to create a simple &\#0034;Hello, world&\#0034; app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.
segment.target: This tutorial teaches you how to use JavaScript and HTML to create a simple &\#0034;Hello, world&\#0034; app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.

segment.source: Create a "Hello, world" app (JS)
segment.target: Create a "Hello, world" app (JS)

segment.source: This tutorial teaches you how to use JavaScript and HTML to create a simple "Hello, world" app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.
segment.target: This tutorial teaches you how to use JavaScript and HTML to create a simple "Hello, world" app that targets the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) on Windows 10.

segment.source: With a single project in Microsoft Visual Studio, you can build an app that runs on any Windows 10 device.
segment.target: With a single project in Microsoft Visual Studio, you can build an app that runs on any Windows 10 device.

segment.source: Here we focus on creating an app that runs equally well on desktop and mobile devices.
segment.target: Here we focus on creating an app that runs equally well on desktop and mobile devices.

segment.source: Important This tutorial is for use with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 and Windows 10.
segment.target: Important This tutorial is for use with Microsoft Visual Studio 2015 and Windows 10.

segment.source: It won't work correctly with earlier versions.
segment.target: It won't work correctly with earlier versions.

segment.source: Here you'll learn how to:
segment.target: Here you'll learn how to:

segment.source: Create a new project
segment.target: Create a new project

segment.source: Add HTML content to your start page
segment.target: Add HTML content to your start page

segment.source: Handle touch, pen, and mouse input
segment.target: Handle touch, pen, and mouse input

segment.source: Run the project on the local desktop and on the phone emulator in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Run the project on the local desktop and on the phone emulator in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Create your own custom styles
segment.target: Create your own custom styles

segment.source: Use a Windows Library for JavaScript control
segment.target: Use a Windows Library for JavaScript control

segment.source: Before you start...
segment.target: Before you start...

segment.source: We're going to jump right into the steps you use to create a simple universal app.
segment.target: We're going to jump right into the steps you use to create a simple universal app.

segment.source: So we strongly recommend that you read and understand the overview information in What's new in Windows 10 and What's a Universal Windows app before you start this tutorial.
segment.target: So we strongly recommend that you read and understand the overview information in What's new in Windows 10 and What's a Universal Windows app before you start this tutorial.

segment.source: To complete this tutorial, you need Windows 10 and Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: To complete this tutorial, you need Windows 10 and Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: See Get set up for more info.
segment.target: See Get set up for more info.

segment.source: We also assume you're using the default window layout in Visual Studio.
segment.target: We also assume you're using the default window layout in Visual Studio.

segment.source: If you change the default layout, you can reset it in the Window menu by using the Reset Window Layout command.
segment.target: If you change the default layout, you can reset it in the Window menu by using the Reset Window Layout command.

segment.source: Step 1: Create a new project in Visual Studio
segment.target: Step 1: Create a new project in Visual Studio

segment.source: Let's create a new app named .
segment.target: Let's create a new app named .

segment.source: Here's how:
segment.target: Here's how:

segment.source: Launch Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Launch Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: The Visual Studio 2015 start screen appears.
segment.target: The Visual Studio 2015 start screen appears.

segment.source: (From now on, we'll refer to Visual Studio 2015 simply as Visual Studio .)
segment.target: (From now on, we'll refer to Visual Studio 2015 simply as Visual Studio .)

segment.source: On the File menu, select NewProject.
segment.target: On the File menu, select NewProject.

segment.source: The New Project dialog appears.
segment.target: The New Project dialog appears.

segment.source: The left pane of the dialog lets you pick the type of templates to display.
segment.target: The left pane of the dialog lets you pick the type of templates to display.

segment.source: In the left pane, expand Installed > Templates > JavaScript > Windows, then pick the Universal template group.
segment.target: In the left pane, expand Installed > Templates > JavaScript > Windows, then pick the Universal template group.

segment.source: The dialog's center pane displays a list of project templates for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: The dialog's center pane displays a list of project templates for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: The New Project window
segment.target: The New Project window

segment.source: For this tutorial, we use the Blank App template.
segment.target: For this tutorial, we use the Blank App template.

segment.source: This template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user interface controls or data.
segment.target: This template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user interface controls or data.

segment.source: You add controls and data to the app over the course of this tutorials.
segment.target: You add controls and data to the app over the course of this tutorials.

segment.source: In the center pane, select the Blank App (Universal Windows) template.
segment.target: In the center pane, select the Blank App (Universal Windows) template.

segment.source: The Blank App template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user-interface controls or data.
segment.target: The Blank App template creates a minimal UWP app that compiles and runs, but contains no user-interface controls or data.

segment.source: You add controls to the app over the course of this tutorial.
segment.target: You add controls to the app over the course of this tutorial.

segment.source: In the Name text box, type "HelloWorld".
segment.target: In the Name text box, type "HelloWorld".

segment.source: Click OK to create the project.
segment.target: Click OK to create the project.

segment.source: Visual Studio creates your project and displays it in the Solution Explorer.
segment.target: Visual Studio creates your project and displays it in the Solution Explorer.

segment.source: Visual Studio Solution Explorer for the HelloWorld project
segment.target: Visual Studio Solution Explorer for the HelloWorld project

segment.source: Although the Blank App is a minimal template, it still contains a handful of files:
segment.target: Although the Blank App is a minimal template, it still contains a handful of files:

segment.source: A manifest file (package.appxmanifest) that describes your app (its name, description, tile, start page, splash screen, and so on) and lists the files that your app contains.
segment.target: A manifest file (package.appxmanifest) that describes your app (its name, description, tile, start page, splash screen, and so on) and lists the files that your app contains.

segment.source: A set of logo images (images/Square150x150Logo.scale-200.png, images/Square44x44Logo.scale-200.png, and images/Wide310x150Logo.scale-200.png)to display in the start menu.
segment.target: A set of logo images (images/Square150x150Logo.scale-200.png, images/Square44x44Logo.scale-200.png, and images/Wide310x150Logo.scale-200.png)to display in the start menu.

segment.source: An image (images/StoreLogo.png) to represent your app in the Windows Store.
segment.target: An image (images/StoreLogo.png) to represent your app in the Windows Store.

segment.source: A splash screen (images/SplashScreen.scale-200.png) to show when your app starts.
segment.target: A splash screen (images/SplashScreen.scale-200.png) to show when your app starts.

segment.source: A start page (default.html) and an accompanying JavaScript file (default.js) that run when your app starts.
segment.target: A start page (default.html) and an accompanying JavaScript file (default.js) that run when your app starts.

segment.source: To view and edit the files, double-click the file in the Solution Explorer.
segment.target: To view and edit the files, double-click the file in the Solution Explorer.

segment.source: These files are essential to all UWP apps using JavaScript.
segment.target: These files are essential to all UWP apps using JavaScript.

segment.source: Any project that you create in Visual Studio contains them.
segment.target: Any project that you create in Visual Studio contains them.

segment.source: Step 2: Launch the app
segment.target: Step 2: Launch the app

segment.source: At this point, you've created a very simple app.
segment.target: At this point, you've created a very simple app.

segment.source: This is a good time to build, deploy, and launch your app and see what it looks like.
segment.target: This is a good time to build, deploy, and launch your app and see what it looks like.

segment.source: You can debug your app on the local machine, in a simulator or emulator, or on a remote device.
segment.target: You can debug your app on the local machine, in a simulator or emulator, or on a remote device.

segment.source: Here's the target device menu in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Here's the target device menu in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Drop-down list of device targets for debugging your app
segment.target: Drop-down list of device targets for debugging your app

segment.source: Start the app on a Desktop device
segment.target: Start the app on a Desktop device

segment.source: By default, the app runs on the local machine.
segment.target: By default, the app runs on the local machine.

segment.source: The target device menu provides several options for debugging your app on devices from the desktop device family.
segment.target: The target device menu provides several options for debugging your app on devices from the desktop device family.

segment.source: Simulator
segment.target: Simulator

segment.source: Local Machine
segment.target: Local Machine

segment.source: Remote Machine
segment.target: Remote Machine

segment.source: To start debugging on the local machine
segment.target: To start debugging on the local machine

segment.source: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, make sure that Local Machine is selected.
segment.target: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, make sure that Local Machine is selected.

segment.source: (It's the default selection.)
segment.target: (It's the default selection.)

segment.source: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) on the toolbar.
segment.target: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) on the toolbar.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.
segment.target: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: Press F5.
segment.target: Press F5.

segment.source: The app opens in a window, and a default splash screen appears first.
segment.target: The app opens in a window, and a default splash screen appears first.

segment.source: The splash screen is defined by an image (SplashScreen.png) and a background color (specified in your app's manifest file).
segment.target: The splash screen is defined by an image (SplashScreen.png) and a background color (specified in your app's manifest file).

segment.source: The splash screen disappears, and then your app appears.
segment.target: The splash screen disappears, and then your app appears.

segment.source: It contains a black screen with the text "Content goes here".
segment.target: It contains a black screen with the text "Content goes here".

segment.source: The HelloWorld app on a PC
segment.target: The HelloWorld app on a PC

segment.source: Press the Windows key to open the Start menu, then show all apps.
segment.target: Press the Windows key to open the Start menu, then show all apps.

segment.source: Notice that deploying the app locally adds its tile to the Start menu.
segment.target: Notice that deploying the app locally adds its tile to the Start menu.

segment.source: To run the app again (not in debugging mode), tap or click its tile in the Start menu.
segment.target: To run the app again (not in debugging mode), tap or click its tile in the Start menu.

segment.source: It doesn't do much—yet—but congratulations, you've built your first UWP app!
segment.target: It doesn't do much—yet—but congratulations, you've built your first UWP app!

segment.source: To stop debugging
segment.target: To stop debugging

segment.source: Click the Stop Debugging button (Stop debugging button) in the toolbar.
segment.target: Click the Stop Debugging button (Stop debugging button) in the toolbar.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: From the Debug menu, click Stop debugging.
segment.target: From the Debug menu, click Stop debugging.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: Close the app window.
segment.target: Close the app window.

segment.source: Start the app on a mobile device emulator
segment.target: Start the app on a mobile device emulator

segment.source: Your app runs on any Windows 10 device, so let’s see how it looks on a Windows Phone.
segment.target: Your app runs on any Windows 10 device, so let’s see how it looks on a Windows Phone.

segment.source: In addition to the options to debug on a desktop device, Visual Studio provides options for deploying and debugging your app on a physical mobile device connected to the computer, or on a mobile device emulator.
segment.target: In addition to the options to debug on a desktop device, Visual Studio provides options for deploying and debugging your app on a physical mobile device connected to the computer, or on a mobile device emulator.

segment.source: You can choose among emulators for devices with different memory and display configurations.
segment.target: You can choose among emulators for devices with different memory and display configurations.

segment.source: Device
segment.target: Device

segment.source: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 512MB
segment.target: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 512MB

segment.source: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 1GB
segment.target: Emulator WVGA 4 inch 1GB

segment.source: etc... (Various emulators in other configurations)
segment.target: etc... (Various emulators in other configurations)

segment.source: It's a good idea to test your app on a device with a small screen and limited memory, so use the Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB option.
segment.target: It's a good idea to test your app on a device with a small screen and limited memory, so use the Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB option.

segment.source: To start debugging on a mobile device emulator
segment.target: To start debugging on a mobile device emulator

segment.source: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, pick Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB.
segment.target: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, pick Emulator 10.0.10240.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB.

segment.source: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) in the toolbar.
segment.target: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) in the toolbar.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.
segment.target: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.

segment.source: Visual Studio starts the selected emulator and then deploys and starts your app.
segment.target: Visual Studio starts the selected emulator and then deploys and starts your app.

segment.source: On the mobile device emulator, the app looks like this.
segment.target: On the mobile device emulator, the app looks like this.

segment.source: Initial app screen on mobile device
segment.target: Initial app screen on mobile device

segment.source: Step 3: Modify your start page
segment.target: Step 3: Modify your start page

segment.source: One of the files that Visual Studio created for you is default.html, your app's start page.
segment.target: One of the files that Visual Studio created for you is default.html, your app's start page.

segment.source: When the app runs, it displays the content of its start page.
segment.target: When the app runs, it displays the content of its start page.

segment.source: The start page also contains references to the app's code files and style sheets.
segment.target: The start page also contains references to the app's code files and style sheets.

segment.source: Here's the start page that Visual Studio created for you:
segment.target: Here's the start page that Visual Studio created for you:

segment.source: Let's add some new content to your default.html file.
segment.target: Let's add some new content to your default.html file.

segment.source: Just as you would add content to any other HTML file, you add your content inside the body element.
segment.target: Just as you would add content to any other HTML file, you add your content inside the body element.

segment.source: You can use HTML5 elements to create your app (with a few exceptions).
segment.target: You can use HTML5 elements to create your app (with a few exceptions).

segment.source: That means you can use HTML5 elements like h1, p, button, div, and img.
segment.target: That means you can use HTML5 elements like h1, p, button, div, and img.

segment.source: To modify your start page
segment.target: To modify your start page

segment.source: Replace the existing content in the body element with a first-level heading that says "Hello, world!", some text that asks the user's name, an input element to accept the user's name, a button, and a div element.
segment.target: Replace the existing content in the body element with a first-level heading that says "Hello, world!", some text that asks the user's name, an input element to accept the user's name, a button, and a div element.

segment.source: Assign IDs to the input, the button, and the div.
segment.target: Assign IDs to the input, the button, and the div.

segment.source: Run the app on the local machine.
segment.target: Run the app on the local machine.

segment.source: It look like this.
segment.target: It look like this.

segment.source: The HelloWorld app with new content
segment.target: The HelloWorld app with new content

segment.source: You can type in the input element, but right now, clicking the button doesn't do anything.
segment.target: You can type in the input element, but right now, clicking the button doesn't do anything.

segment.source: Some objects, such as button, can send messages when certain events occur.
segment.target: Some objects, such as button, can send messages when certain events occur.

segment.source: These event messages give you the opportunity to take some action in response to the event.
segment.target: These event messages give you the opportunity to take some action in response to the event.

segment.source: You put code to respond to the event in an event handler method.
segment.target: You put code to respond to the event in an event handler method.

segment.source: In the next steps, we create an event handler for the button that displays a personalized greeting.
segment.target: In the next steps, we create an event handler for the button that displays a personalized greeting.

segment.source: We add our event handler code to our default.js file.
segment.target: We add our event handler code to our default.js file.

segment.source: Step 4: Create an event handler
segment.target: Step 4: Create an event handler

segment.source: When we created our new project, Visual Studio created a /js/default.js file for us.
segment.target: When we created our new project, Visual Studio created a /js/default.js file for us.

segment.source: This file contains code for handling your app's life cycle.
segment.target: This file contains code for handling your app's life cycle.

segment.source: It's also where you write additional code that provides interactivity for your default.html file.
segment.target: It's also where you write additional code that provides interactivity for your default.html file.

segment.source: Open the default.js file.
segment.target: Open the default.js file.

segment.source: Before we start adding our own code, let's take a look at the first and the last few lines of code in the file:
segment.target: Before we start adding our own code, let's take a look at the first and the last few lines of code in the file:

segment.source: You might be wondering what's going on here.
segment.target: You might be wondering what's going on here.

segment.source: These lines of code wrap the rest of the default.js code in a self-executing anonymous function.
segment.target: These lines of code wrap the rest of the default.js code in a self-executing anonymous function.

segment.source: A self-executing anonymous function makes it easier to avoid naming conflicts or situations where you accidently modify a value that you didn't intend to modify.
segment.target: A self-executing anonymous function makes it easier to avoid naming conflicts or situations where you accidently modify a value that you didn't intend to modify.

segment.source: It also keeps unnecessary identifiers out of the global namespace, which helps performance.
segment.target: It also keeps unnecessary identifiers out of the global namespace, which helps performance.

segment.source: It looks a little strange, but it's a good programming practice.
segment.target: It looks a little strange, but it's a good programming practice.

segment.source: The next line of code turns on strict mode for your JavaScript code.
segment.target: The next line of code turns on strict mode for your JavaScript code.

segment.source: Strict mode provides additional error checking for your code.
segment.target: Strict mode provides additional error checking for your code.

segment.source: For example, it prevents you from using implicitly declared variables or assigning a value to a read-only property.
segment.target: For example, it prevents you from using implicitly declared variables or assigning a value to a read-only property.

segment.source: Take a look at the rest of the code in default.js.
segment.target: Take a look at the rest of the code in default.js.

segment.source: It handles your app's activated and checkpoint events.
segment.target: It handles your app's activated and checkpoint events.

segment.source: We go into more detail about these events later.
segment.target: We go into more detail about these events later.

segment.source: For now, just know that the activated event fires when your app starts.
segment.target: For now, just know that the activated event fires when your app starts.

segment.source: Let's define an event handler for your button.
segment.target: Let's define an event handler for your button.

segment.source: Our new event handler gets the user's name from the input control and uses it to output a greeting to the div element that you created in the last section.
segment.target: Our new event handler gets the user's name from the input control and uses it to output a greeting to the div element that you created in the last section.

segment.source: Using events that work for touch, mouse, and pen input
segment.target: Using events that work for touch, mouse, and pen input

segment.source: In a UWP app, you don’t need to worry about the differences between touch, mouse, and other forms of pointer input.
segment.target: In a UWP app, you don’t need to worry about the differences between touch, mouse, and other forms of pointer input.

segment.source: You can just use events that you know, like click, and they work for all forms of input.
segment.target: You can just use events that you know, like click, and they work for all forms of input.

segment.source: Tip Your app can also use the new MSPointer\* and MSGesture\* events, which work for touch, mouse, and pen input and can provide additional info about the device that triggered the event.
segment.target: Tip Your app can also use the new MSPointer\* and MSGesture\* events, which work for touch, mouse, and pen input and can provide additional info about the device that triggered the event.

segment.source: For more info, see Responding to user interaction and Gestures, manipulations, and interactions.
segment.target: For more info, see Responding to user interaction and Gestures, manipulations, and interactions.

segment.source: Let's go ahead and create the event handler.
segment.target: Let's go ahead and create the event handler.

segment.source: To create the event handler
segment.target: To create the event handler

segment.source: In default.js, after the app.oncheckpoint event handler and before the call to app.start, create a click event handler function named that takes a single parameter named .
segment.target: In default.js, after the app.oncheckpoint event handler and before the call to app.start, create a click event handler function named that takes a single parameter named .

segment.source: You added your event handler to default.js.
segment.target: You added your event handler to default.js.

segment.source: Now you need to register it.
segment.target: Now you need to register it.

segment.source: Step 5: Register the event handler when your app launches
segment.target: Step 5: Register the event handler when your app launches

segment.source: The only thing we need to do now is register the event handler with the button.
segment.target: The only thing we need to do now is register the event handler with the button.

segment.source: The recommended way to register an event handler is to call addEventListener from our code.
segment.target: The recommended way to register an event handler is to call addEventListener from our code.

segment.source: A good place to register the event handler is when our app is activated.
segment.target: A good place to register the event handler is when our app is activated.

segment.source: Fortunately, Visual Studio generated some code for us in our default.js file that handles our app's activation: the app.onactivated event handler.
segment.target: Fortunately, Visual Studio generated some code for us in our default.js file that handles our app's activation: the app.onactivated event handler.

segment.source: Let's take a look at this code.
segment.target: Let's take a look at this code.

segment.source: Inside the onactivated handler, the code checks to see what type of activation occurred.
segment.target: Inside the onactivated handler, the code checks to see what type of activation occurred.

segment.source: There are many different types of activations.
segment.target: There are many different types of activations.

segment.source: For example, your app is activated when the user launches your app and when the user wants to open a file that is associated with your app.
segment.target: For example, your app is activated when the user launches your app and when the user wants to open a file that is associated with your app.

segment.source: (For more info, see App lifecycle.)
segment.target: (For more info, see App lifecycle.)

segment.source: We're interested in the launch activation.
segment.target: We're interested in the launch activation.

segment.source: An app is launched whenever it is not running and then a user activates it.
segment.target: An app is launched whenever it is not running and then a user activates it.

segment.source: If the activation is a launch activation, the code checks to see how the app was shut down the last time it ran.
segment.target: If the activation is a launch activation, the code checks to see how the app was shut down the last time it ran.

segment.source: Then it calls WinJS.UI.processAll.
segment.target: Then it calls WinJS.UI.processAll.

segment.source: It calls WinJS.UI.processAll regardless of whether the app had been shut down in the past or whether this is the very first time it's being launched.
segment.target: It calls WinJS.UI.processAll regardless of whether the app had been shut down in the past or whether this is the very first time it's being launched.

segment.source: The WinJS.UI.processAll is enclosed in a call to the setPromise method, which makes sure the splash screen isn't taken down until the app's page is ready.
segment.target: The WinJS.UI.processAll is enclosed in a call to the setPromise method, which makes sure the splash screen isn't taken down until the app's page is ready.

segment.source: Tip The WinJS.UI.processAll function scans your default.html file for WinJS controls and initializes them.
segment.target: Tip The WinJS.UI.processAll function scans your default.html file for WinJS controls and initializes them.

segment.source: So far, we haven't added any of these controls, but it's a good idea to leave this code in case you want to add them later.
segment.target: So far, we haven't added any of these controls, but it's a good idea to leave this code in case you want to add them later.

segment.source: A good place to register event handlers for non-WinJS controls is just after the call to WinJS.UI.processAll.
segment.target: A good place to register event handlers for non-WinJS controls is just after the call to WinJS.UI.processAll.

segment.source: To register your event handler
segment.target: To register your event handler

segment.source: In the onactivated event handler in default.js, retrieve and use addEventListener to register our event handler for the click event.
segment.target: In the onactivated event handler in default.js, retrieve and use addEventListener to register our event handler for the click event.

segment.source: Add this code after the call to WinJS.UI.processAll.
segment.target: Add this code after the call to WinJS.UI.processAll.

segment.source: Here's the complete code for our updated default.js file:
segment.target: Here's the complete code for our updated default.js file:

segment.source: Run the app.
segment.target: Run the app.

segment.source: When you enter your name in the text box and click the button, the app displays a personalized greeting.
segment.target: When you enter your name in the text box and click the button, the app displays a personalized greeting.

segment.source: Here's how it looks on the local machine and in the emulator.
segment.target: Here's how it looks on the local machine and in the emulator.

segment.source: A personalized greeting from the HelloWorld app
segment.target: A personalized greeting from the HelloWorld app

segment.source: A personalized greeting from the HelloWorld app
segment.target: A personalized greeting from the HelloWorld app

segment.source: Note If you're curious as to why we use addEventListener to register our event in code rather than setting the onclick event in our HTML, see Coding basic apps for a detailed explanation.
segment.target: Note If you're curious as to why we use addEventListener to register our event in code rather than setting the onclick event in our HTML, see Coding basic apps for a detailed explanation.

segment.source: Step 6: Add a Windows Library for JavaScript control
segment.target: Step 6: Add a Windows Library for JavaScript control

segment.source: In addition to standard HTML controls, your app can use any of the controls in the Windows Library for JavaScript, such as the WinJS.UI.DatePicker, WinJS.UI.FlipView, WinjS.UI.ListView, and WinJS.UI.Rating controls.
segment.target: In addition to standard HTML controls, your app can use any of the controls in the Windows Library for JavaScript, such as the WinJS.UI.DatePicker, WinJS.UI.FlipView, WinjS.UI.ListView, and WinJS.UI.Rating controls.

segment.source: Unlike HTML controls, WinJS controls don't have dedicated markup elements: you can't create a Rating control by adding a element, for example.
segment.target: Unlike HTML controls, WinJS controls don't have dedicated markup elements: you can't create a Rating control by adding a element, for example.

segment.source: To add a WinJS control, you create a div element and use the data-win-control attribute to specify the type of control you want.
segment.target: To add a WinJS control, you create a div element and use the data-win-control attribute to specify the type of control you want.

segment.source: To add a Rating control, you set the attribute to "WinJS.UI.Rating".
segment.target: To add a Rating control, you set the attribute to "WinJS.UI.Rating".

segment.source: Let's add a Rating control to your app.
segment.target: Let's add a Rating control to your app.

segment.source: In your default.html file, add a label and a Rating control after the div.
segment.target: In your default.html file, add a label and a Rating control after the div.

segment.source: Run the app on the local machine.
segment.target: Run the app on the local machine.

segment.source: Notice the new Rating control.
segment.target: Notice the new Rating control.

segment.source: The Hello, world app, with a Windows Library for JavaScript control
segment.target: The Hello, world app, with a Windows Library for JavaScript control

segment.source: Right now, clicking the Rating control changes the rating, but it doesn't do anything else.
segment.target: Right now, clicking the Rating control changes the rating, but it doesn't do anything else.

segment.source: Let's use an event handler to do something when the user changes the rating.
segment.target: Let's use an event handler to do something when the user changes the rating.

segment.source: Step 7: Register an event handler for a Windows Library for JavaScript control
segment.target: Step 7: Register an event handler for a Windows Library for JavaScript control

segment.source: Registering an event handler for a WinJS control is a little different than registering an event handler for a standard HTML control.
segment.target: Registering an event handler for a WinJS control is a little different than registering an event handler for a standard HTML control.

segment.source: Earlier, we mentioned that the onactivated event handler calls WinJS.UI.processAll method to initialize WinJS in your markup.
segment.target: Earlier, we mentioned that the onactivated event handler calls WinJS.UI.processAll method to initialize WinJS in your markup.

segment.source: The WinJS.UI.processAll is enclosed in a call to the setPromise method.
segment.target: The WinJS.UI.processAll is enclosed in a call to the setPromise method.

segment.source: If Rating were a standard HTML control, you could add your event handler after this call to WinJS.UI.processAll.
segment.target: If Rating were a standard HTML control, you could add your event handler after this call to WinJS.UI.processAll.

segment.source: But it's a little more complicated for a WinJS control like our Rating.
segment.target: But it's a little more complicated for a WinJS control like our Rating.

segment.source: Because WinJS.UI.processAll creates the Rating control for us, we can't add the event handler to Rating until after WinJS.UI.processAll has finished its processing.
segment.target: Because WinJS.UI.processAll creates the Rating control for us, we can't add the event handler to Rating until after WinJS.UI.processAll has finished its processing.

segment.source: If WinJS.UI.processAll were a typical method, we could register the Rating event handler right after we call it.
segment.target: If WinJS.UI.processAll were a typical method, we could register the Rating event handler right after we call it.

segment.source: But the WinJS.UI.processAll method is asynchronous, so any code that follows it might run before WinJS.UI.processAll completes.
segment.target: But the WinJS.UI.processAll method is asynchronous, so any code that follows it might run before WinJS.UI.processAll completes.

segment.source: So, what do we do?
segment.target: So, what do we do?

segment.source: We use a Promise object to receive notification when WinJS.UI.processAll completes.
segment.target: We use a Promise object to receive notification when WinJS.UI.processAll completes.

segment.source: Like all asynchronous WinJS methods, WinJS.UI.processAll returns a Promise object.
segment.target: Like all asynchronous WinJS methods, WinJS.UI.processAll returns a Promise object.

segment.source: A Promise is a "promise" that something will happen in the future; when that thing happens, the Promise is said to have completed.
segment.target: A Promise is a "promise" that something will happen in the future; when that thing happens, the Promise is said to have completed.

segment.source: Promise objects have a then method that takes a "completed" function as a parameter.
segment.target: Promise objects have a then method that takes a "completed" function as a parameter.

segment.source: The Promise calls this function when it completes.
segment.target: The Promise calls this function when it completes.

segment.source: By adding your code to a "completed" function and passing it to the Promise object's then method, you can be sure your code executes after WinJS.UI.processAll is complete.
segment.target: By adding your code to a "completed" function and passing it to the Promise object's then method, you can be sure your code executes after WinJS.UI.processAll is complete.

segment.source: Let's output the rating value when the user selects a rating.
segment.target: Let's output the rating value when the user selects a rating.

segment.source: In your default.html file, create a div element to display the rating value and give it the id "ratingOutput".
segment.target: In your default.html file, create a div element to display the rating value and give it the id "ratingOutput".

segment.source: In our default.js file, create an event handler for the Rating control's change event named .
segment.target: In our default.js file, create an event handler for the Rating control's change event named .

segment.source: The eventInfo parameter contains a detail.tentativeRating property that provides the new user rating.
segment.target: The eventInfo parameter contains a detail.tentativeRating property that provides the new user rating.

segment.source: Retrieve this value and display it in the output div.
segment.target: Retrieve this value and display it in the output div.

segment.source: Run the app.
segment.target: Run the app.

segment.source: When you select a rating value, it outputs the numeric value below the Rating control.
segment.target: When you select a rating value, it outputs the numeric value below the Rating control.

segment.source: The completed Hello world app on a PC
segment.target: The completed Hello world app on a PC

segment.target: The completed Hello world app on a phone

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: Congratulations, you've created your first app for Windows 10 and the UWP using JavaScript and HTML!
segment.target: Congratulations, you've created your first app for Windows 10 and the UWP using JavaScript and HTML!
